awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Remote Characterization of Microbial Mats in Taylor Valley, Antarctica, through In Situ Sampling and Spectral Validation
awd_abstract_narration:
Microbial mats are found throughout the McMurdo Dry Valleys where summer snowmelt provides liquid water that allows these mats to flourish. Researchers have long studied the environmental conditions microbial mats need to grow. Despite these efforts, it has been difficult to develop a broad picture of these unique ecosystems. Recent advances in satellite technology now provide researchers an exciting new tool to study these special Antarctic ecosystems from space using the unique spectral signatures associated with microbial mats. This new technology not only offers the promise that microbial mats can be mapped and studied from space, this research will also help protect these delicate environments from potentially harmful human impacts that can occur when studying them from the ground. This project will use satellite imagery and spectroscopic techniques to identify and map microbial mat communities and relate their properties and distributions to both field and lab-based measurements. This research provides an exciting new tool to help document and understand the distribution of a major component of the Antarctic ecosystem in the McMurdo Dry Valleys.

The goal of this project is to establish quantitative relationships between spectral signatures derived from orbit and the physiological status and biogeochemical properties of microbial mat communities in Taylor Valley, Antarctica, as measured by field and laboratory analyses on collected samples. The goal wioll be met by (1) refining atmospheric correction techniques using in situ radiometric rectification to derive accurate surface spectra; (2) collecting multispectral orbital images concurrent with in situ sampling and spectral measurements in the field to ensure temporal comparability; (3) measuring sediment, water, and microbial mat samples for organic and inorganic carbon content, essential biogeochemical nutrients, and chlorophyll-a to determine relevant mat characteristics; and (4) quantitatively associating these laboratory-derived characteristics with field-derived and orbital spectral signatures and parameters.  The result of this work will be a more robust quantitative link between the distribution of microbial mat communities and their biogeochemical properties to landscape-scale spectral signatures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to link high resolution satellite imagery to on-the-ground observations of microbial mats in Taylor Valley in the McMurdo Dry Valleys (MDV) in Antarctica. The MDV is the largest ice-free area in Antarctica and is an important ecosystem to study because (1) it is a sentinel polar ecosystem that is crucial for understanding climate change and (2) it is a relatively simple, yet extreme ecosystem, that provides a unique natural lab for testing ecological theory. Because of the high scientific importance of the MDV, the McMurdo Dry Valleys Long Term Ecological Research (MCM-LTER) has been funded by the NSF to collect long-term ecological and environmental data since 1992, including data about the microbial mats, which are dominated by cyanobacteria, that typically occur in and around areas that see meltwater in the summer. These microbial mats are the dominant primary producers in the MDV and they provide habitats for other organisms (such as diatoms, nematodes, protists, etc.), and their ecology has been studied extensively by the MCM LTER program. However, a comprehensive mapping of microbial mat distribution in the dry valleys has been lacking because such a field effort would be nearly impossible given the expense of deploying a field crew to carry out the work in such a remote ecosystem. Remote techniques for detecting, characterizing, and mapping microbial mats could provide a crucial tool for understanding landscape scale shifts in the distribution and characteristics of these important primary producers in the MDV.  

Thus, our goal in this project was to establish quantitative relationships between multispectral imagery collected from satellites and the characteristics of microbial mat communities in Taylor Valley as measured by field and laboratory analyses on collected samples. The overall result of this work is the first quantitative link between the distribution of microbial mat communities, their health, and their biogeochemical properties to landscape-scale spectral signatures.

Even prior to any field validation, our research team was able to confidently identify the presence of photosynthetic microbial communities in and around Antarctic stream channels using their diagnostic spectral signatures as identified from orbit (Salvatore, 2015; Salvatore et al., 2020). This work demonstrated the potential of high-resolution satellite image analysis in characterizing the Antarctic terrestrial and wetland ecosystems. Virginia Tech graduate student Sarah Power followed up these remote analyses with the first field validation effort, which demonstrated a strong link between photosynthetic metrics (e.g., Normalized Difference Vegetation Index, NDVI) and the measured abundance and ecological properties of microbial mats as characterized on the ground. This work also suggested that remote sensing data could be used to further refine our estimates of landscape stocks of organic carbon.

Sokol et al. (2020) used these remote sensing data and initial model outputs to validate their ecological modeling efforts to understand the drivers of observed biodiversity patterns across the landscape. They found that the observed distribution of diatoms residing in patches of microbial mats mapped using the methods described by Salvatore et al. (2020, 2021) and Power et al. (2020) best matched the hypothesis that dispersal dynamics are the primary organizer of biodiversity, with aeolian dispersal as a likely facilitator.

Lastly, Salvatore et al. (2021) presented the first validated linear unmixing model for the Fryxell basin of Taylor Valley, demonstrating that remote sensing data could be calibrated to surface reflectance, fed a model of in situ-derived surface endmembers, and calculate accurate estimates of microbial mat abundances at each pixel. These results were used to estimate the total amount of photosynthetically active biomass in the Fryxell basin, predicting more than one million kilograms of carbon present in the basin at that one given point in time.

Northern Arizona University (NAU) graduate student Schuyler Borges is wrapping up work to catalog and submit a comprehensive spectral database to the Environmental Data Initiative for long-term storage and to make the data more easily accessible by the scientific community. These efforts are expected to be completed in 2024, concurrent with the publication of a summary manuscript led by Borges.

The ability to characterize, continually monitor, and quantify the abundance of photosynthetic communities remotely using orbital assets is a revolutionary tool in the investigation of Antarctic ecology. The work that was performed under this award has elevated these capabilities from "conceptual" to "practical," allowing researchers to use these data and have confidence in their results.
